repnme.cdata!:
Serbia and Montenegro - Second Private and
            Financial Sector Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This Second Private and Financial Sector
            Adjustment Credit (PFSAC) Project is rated satisfactory,
            with a likely sustainability, and substantial institutional
            development impacts. In particular, the project team
            recognized the need for a clean, and transparent
            privatization process, and for tailoring the reform design
            to the specific features, and economic culture of the
            country, resulting in a hard-hitting, and results-focused
            project, yet realistic reform program, as well. One of the
            main reasons this project achieved its ambitious agenda, was
            that a vast technical assistance (TA) provision supported
            the Government in implementing its program, which included
            both Bank and donor financing. The TA eased not only the
            privatizations specified by conditionalities, and by the new
            laws being drafted, but also the critical institution
            building, required to implement changes, and sustain the
            program in the long run. Other lessons reinforce the
            importance of donor coordination, of an integrated approach
            necessary to implement reforms in both the financial and
            enterprise sectors, and, for establishing a legal framework,
            while focusing on institutional capacity and enforcement.

5249558.trustfund:
TF051355-PHRD-YUGOSLAVIA: SECOND PRIVATE
            AND FINANCIAL SECTOR ADJUSTMENT

repnme.cdata!:
Serbia and Montenegro - Second Private and
            Financial Sector Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Private and Financial Sector
            Adjustment Credit (PFSAC II) will support the governments
            Serbia and Montenegro, and its largest constituent member
            state, Serbia, in the implementation of regulatory,
            institutional, and structural reforms seeking to
            significantly accelerate private sector-led growth through:
            (i) improving the business environment by means of
            comprehensive reform of enterprise entry, operation and
            exit; (ii) strengthening the financial system by privatizing
            and / or liquidating majority state-owned banks and
            improving the environment under which banks and other
            financial intermediaries operate; and (iii) privatizing and
            restructuring socially-owned enterprises that crowd out
            private sector growth, hamper banking sector recovery, and
            incur significant fiscal and quasi-fiscal costs.
            Accordingly the project will be focused in the following
            areas: reform of business enabling environment, reform of
            financial sector regulatory and supervisory framework,
            banking sector reform, and enterprise sector reform.  The
            credit will be a two tranche operation whose design
            incorporates the lessons from the implementation of PFSAC I,
            as well as from transition reforms in the Europe and Central
            A region during the past decade.  The main benefit of the
            proposed credit will be the facilitation of faster private
            sector growth and job creation, supported by a healthier and
            more developed financial system.
